model_completion: Stroke is a medical emergency that occurs when blood flow to the brain is interrupted or reduced. This can lead to cell death in the affected area of the brain, which can result in permanent damage or death. Common symptoms of a stroke include sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm or leg, especially on one side of the body; sudden confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech; sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes; and sudden trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance or coordination.

Strokes are caused by a blockage or bleeding in the brain. The most common symptoms of a stroke include sudden numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body; sudden confusion or trouble speaking; sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes; and sudden trouble walking or loss of balance. If you experience any of these symptoms, it's important to call 911 right away.

Stroke is a medical emergency that requires immediate treatment. The sooner a person receives treatment, the better their chances of recovery. Treatment options include medications to dissolve blood clots and restore blood flow to the brain, as well as surgery to remove the blockage. People who have had a stroke may also benefit from rehabilitation therapy to help them regain function in their arms and legs.

Stroke is a medical emergency that occurs when blood flow to the brain is interrupted or reduced. This can be caused by a blocked artery (ischemic stroke) or a burst blood vessel (hemorrhagic stroke). Risk factors for stroke include high blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, obesity, heart disease and atrial fibrillation. People who have had a stroke in the past are also at increased risk of having another stroke.

Ischemic strokes occur when blood flow to the brain is blocked, while hemorrhagic strokes occur when a blood vessel in the brain bursts. The most common cause of ischemic stroke is atherosclerosis, or hardening of the arteries. Atherosclerosis can lead to plaque buildup in the arteries, which can block blood flow to the brain. Hemorrhagic strokes are often caused by high blood pressure, which can weaken blood vessels in the brain.

Stroke is the leading cause of disability in the United States. There are two types of strokes: ischemic and hemorrhagic. Ischemic strokes occur when blood flow to the brain is blocked, while hemorrhagic strokes occur when a blood vessel in the brain bursts. Risk factors for stroke include high blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, obesity, heart disease, high cholesterol, atrial fibrillation and family history.

Insomnia is a sleep disorder that causes people to have trouble falling asleep, staying asleep or both. People with insomnia may have one or more of the following symptoms: waking up often during the night, waking up too early in the morning, feeling tired upon waking, having difficulty concentrating and irritability. Insomnia can be caused by medical conditions such as arthritis, asthma, cancer, depression, heartburn, hyperthyroidism, Parkinson's disease, pregnancy and restless legs syndrome. It can also be caused by lifestyle factors such as alcohol use, caffeine consumption, napping, smoking and stress.

Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breasts. Symptoms of breast cancer include a lump in the breast, change in breast size or shape, dimpling of skin, nipple discharge other than breast milk, redness or swelling of the breast and pain in the breast. It is important for women to know what is normal for their breasts so they can report any changes to their health care provider right away.

Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breasts. Breast cancer can be invasive or noninvasive, and it can also be benign or malignant. Invasive breast cancer spreads beyond the ducts or lobes of the breast to other parts of the body, such as the lymph nodes, bones or liver. Noninvasive breast cancer remains in the ducts or lobes of the breast. Benign breast cancer is not life-threatening and does not spread to other parts of the body. Malignant breast cancer is life-threatening and can spread to other parts of the body.

Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breasts. Breast cancer can be treated with surgery, radiation, chemotherapy and hormonal therapy. Surgery to remove the tumor is the most common treatment for early-stage breast cancer. If the cancer has spread to other parts of the body, chemotherapy and hormone therapy may be used.

Invasive breast cancer is breast cancer that has spread outside the ducts or lobules to other parts of the breast. There are many different subtypes of invasive breast cancer. Serotonin syndrome is a condition that occurs when there is too much serotonin in the brain. Symptoms of serotonin syndrome include agitation, hallucinations, increased body temperature, increased heart rate and muscle rigidity. People with serotonin syndrome may also experience nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of coordination and seizures. Treatment for serotonin syndrome includes discontinuing the medication that caused the condition and administering medications to counteract the effects of the excess serotonin.

Cirrhosis is a condition in which the liver is damaged and scarred. This damage prevents the liver from working properly, and it can lead to serious health problems. The most common cause of cirrhosis is alcohol abuse, but other causes include hepatitis C, fatty liver disease, autoimmune diseases and blocked blood vessels in the liver. Symptoms of cirrhosis include fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, weight loss, abdominal pain, jaundice and swelling in the legs.

This can be caused by many different conditions, including alcohol abuse, hepatitis C, fatty liver disease and autoimmune diseases. The most common symptoms of cirrhosis are jaundice, itching, weight loss, nausea and vomiting. A doctor will perform a physical exam and order blood tests to diagnose cirrhosis.

Cirrhosis is a condition in which the liver becomes scarred and damaged. This can be caused by alcohol abuse, hepatitis or other conditions. Treatment for cirrhosis depends on the cause of the disease. People with cirrhosis may need to stop drinking alcohol, take medications to slow down the progression of the disease and avoid certain foods that can make the condition worse.

Cirrhosis is a condition in which the liver becomes severely damaged and scarred. People who have cirrhosis are at an increased risk for liver cancer, liver failure, and other serious complications.

People with cirrhosis should avoid alcohol, which is a major cause of the disease. They should also limit their intake of fatty foods and eat a healthy diet that includes fruits and vegetables. People with cirrhosis should get vaccinated against hepatitis A and B, as well as influenza and pneumococcal diseases. They should also be screened for liver cancer and monitored for signs of depression.

Heat stroke is a life-threatening condition that occurs when the body's temperature rises to 104 degrees Fahrenheit or higher. Anxiety is a normal emotion that everyone experiences at some point in their life. However, when anxiety becomes excessive and interferes with daily activities, it may be a sign of an anxiety disorder. Symptoms of anxiety disorders vary depending on the type of disorder, but can include excessive worrying, irritability, fatigue, muscle tension, difficulty concentrating and sleep problems.

Anxiety disorders can be treated with a variety of medications and therapies. Therapy is also helpful in treating anxiety disorders, and there are many different types of therapy that can help people manage their symptoms.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a condition that affects the large intestine. It causes abdominal pain, cramping and diarrhea or constipation.
